tests/unit/test_configloader.py.message:
If I understand correctly, strings like `value` are already interned, e.g.

  >>> a = "value"
  >>> b = "value"
  >>> a is b
  True

Perhaps it would be better to test longer string, like "a value"
Thanks for the feedback. Would you know why the yaml module does not do that by default?

I don't know but I guess it's because pyyaml is for general purpose use and such an optimization only has advantages if there are many equal strings that are read. If that's not the case intern() imposes a small runtime overhead per string for no benefit. So I think it's actually correct to not do that without knowing the use case.

The strings in your example are automatically interned because they follow some rules. One of those rules is that they are compile time constants. Dynamic strings like produced by the yaml parser are not automatically interned. The test case also fails without the explicit intern.

I wouldn't -1 this, but since there are some more significant changes I'm requesting below, it might be nice to go ahead and tidy this up.

I think it's fine to keep this caveat in the docs, though I don't think it's fair to blame the cache.

This was true before too -- there is no global coordination, so even if we performed zk queries for everything in real time, multiple launchers would still race to fill the quota.  That race could occur over seconds or even minutes as they performed cloud operations.  Whereas the additional skew introduced by using a cached node list is on the order of milliseconds.

It would me more correct to say that because multiple launchers do not coordinate with each other the limits are not guaranteed to be exact.

nodepool/driver/__init__.py.message:
It would be helpful to describe what this is and what it's used for.  But I'm not sure we'll be able to keep it as-is -- se the comment about removing the estimatedQuotaUsed calls.

I think the simplest thing would be to leave the existing system alone, and then add a new launcher method that iterates over all the ZK nodes and returns a QuotaInformation object.  You can use the nodeIterator to make sure we're iterating over the TreeCache which means we don't need to talk to ZK.  It should be fairly efficient.

I think it would be better if we could avoid getting this far -- a fair bit of work has already been done needlessly to get to this point: we've locked the node request, created a request handler, added it to the launcher's list of ongoing requests, and then we're going to immediately unlock the request and remove the request handler record because it's done.

If we could perform this check inside the _assignHandlers method in the launcher, we could avoid all of that (especially the zk writes).  That could get pretty important in a bad situation, where a tenant is fully at quota and still has lots of requests in the queue; we would need to lock and unlock every one of them just to get past them to any requests from other tenants that are behind them.

Now, there's still a race condition, in that another launcher could fulfill a request which puts the tenant at quota between the check in _assignHandlers and here.  But there's already a race condition even with only this check -- two launchers could be executing this code at exactly the same time.  This is a situation that is unique to cluster-wide quota calculations -- we don't have it anywhere else in nodepool.

Fixing that race condition would be very costly indeed (we would either need to add some kind of tenant lock for all providers, or check the tenant quota yet again after fulfilling the request to see if we need to give it back).  But perhaps we're okay with the possibility a tenant might go over quota due to a race condition across providers.  If so, then we don't need to solve that problem.  And if we're okay with that, then we probably don't need a second check here and can just move this to _assignHandlers.

nodepool/driver/openstack/handler.py.message: I'm a little concerned here.  Several calls to self.manager.estimatedNodepoolQuotaUsed have been removed from hasRemainingQuota in favor of using this value.  But this value is only set when a NodeRequestHandler is created.  They can live for quite a long time and exist in a sort of suspended state while they wait for quota to become available.  I'm not convinced we can remove those calls.

nodepool/launcher.py.message: We usually log things we don't do (especially things that we repeatedly don't do, like this) at debug level.  Otherwise a user running at info level would see this message over and over.  Note that this is similar to line 128 above or 182 below.

Imagine one large tenant with thousands of requests, and it's at tenant quota.  assignHandlers is going to call hasTenantQuota for every one of those requests, and each of those calls is going to iterate over all of the the nodes in ZK (and there should be a lot, because that big tenant is at quota).  That makes this polynomial time.

The easiest fix would probably be to do a short (30 seconds?) TTL cache on getUsedQutoaForTenant.  Then we're back to linear time for assignHandlers.

Those are good points; I stand corrected on the nodeIterator cache :).  The nodeIterator uses cached data to provide the actual node info, but the list of nodes still comes from ZK.  So at least we won't be performing nodes*requests fetches of data, but we will perform a get_children for each request that we consider processing.  Maybe we can reduce that by altering nodeIterator to use the cache to provide the list of nodes for this?  It should be almost accurate (modulo the lag introduced by the ZK watch firing).

This might need to be an additional argument to nodeIterator if the existing usages of it are expecting an authoritative list of nodes.

If that's difficult, I agree it's not a showstopper, but I think it might be relatively simple and still sufficiently accurate for this purpose.

It's possible if the tests run very quickly we might see the race and so we might need to make sure all the nodes the test expects are in the tree cache before proceeding.

Referring to your comment on patch set 3 [1], the nodeIterator is already a cached view of the nodes in zk and should be quite efficient.

Introducing a ttl_cache here would be difficult at least at the corresponding unit tests because we'd either need to make sure the cache is disabled for the tests (ttl=0) or make the tests pause for at least ttl+1 at several points for them to not be flaky (this potentially introduces a considerable time penalty, depending on the chosen ttl value).

Also, I'm a bit concerned that a ttl-cached view on the tenant quota would make the race condition you mentioned here [2] even worse.

So all in all I'd rather cope with the additional iteration over the cached/local node list.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/nodepool/+/800765/3/nodepool/driver/__init__.py#384
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/nodepool/+/800765/3/nodepool/driver/__init__.py#585

Note that 785821 adds resources so I think you could account for them using this; see ~

cinderclient/v3/volume_snapshots.py.message: if force evaluates to False, should we fail this request on client side? Since we know it is going to fail on API

if the value isn't boolean-ish, this call will raise the ValueError that we catch at line 143.  If it can be converted to boolean and is False, we raise at line 142 and get handled by the same except block.

I've been thinking about this, though, and I think I am raising the wrong exception at line 144, which is what the shell raises when you try to give a command an undefined option.  I think what I should do is raise a different ValueError here (one that has language similar to what the corresponding error on the cinder side says), and then call this from the shell function in a try block, and if I get a ValueError, convert it over there into an UnsupportedAttribute and then raise.

So I will definitely be revising this.
if force=test-foo, we reach the second case mentioned below
if force=False, we reach the first case mentioned below

IIUC this will be executed in 2 cases
1) if force=False, which is desired
2) force=<invalid value>, the message says that we are ignoring everything except force=True so that makes sense but again is it ok to have same error raised for force=False (which was a valid value before) and any arbitrary value like force=test-foo
Makes sense, Thanks for the explanation.

Here's the strategy in change I6d45aeab0651, that introduces mv 3.66 in cinder:
- we will silently ignore force=True to accommodate scripts that already include 'force=true' in the request
- if the error message says "force" is not allowed, that's going to be confusing because if you try force=True, the call succeeds, so we explain the "silent ignore" in the error message so it's clear it's designed behavior and not a bug
- we don't accept force=False because that would seem to imply that if a volume is in-use, the snapshot request should fail, whereas the whole point of mv 3.66 is that there is no such thing as a "forced" snapshot anymore

So here on the client side, officially 'force' is not a valid option to the snapshot-create call after mv 3.66.  However, we want to silently accept it (for backward compatibility, just as we did in the API).  So the point of the error message is to say that the *option* is bad, not that the *value* you supplied is bad.  Hence, I don't think we need to distinguish between a really bad value ('test-foo') vs. a formerly-good-but-now-bad-value ('false').

Finally, the error message defined as MV_3_66_FORCE_FLAG_ERROR would only be seen by someone who uses this class directly.  From the shell, the user will see:

  $ cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.66 snapshot-create --force false volume-name
  ERROR: 'force' argument is not allowed after microversion 3.65

which is the same thing you'd see if we had not defined --force as a suppressed option for the new do_create_snapshot() function, and had simply added an "end_version" to the definition of that option on the old do_create_snapshot().  The difference is that if the user uses --force=True with mv 3.66, the call will succeed.

So I think this really is the correct approach (or to be precise, this approach is the most consistent with what we decided to do on the cinder side).

I think it's better to avoid using a mutable object as a default argument [1][2].

Isn't possible to write the following inside ``do_request`` and change all ``headers={}`` to ``headers=None``?

```
if headers is None:
    headers = {}
```


[1] http://pylint-messages.wikidot.com/messages:w0102

/COMMIT_MSG.message: why not do the same for DbQuotaDriver?

Because this driver handles the expiration reservations in a different way. "DbQuotaNoLockDriver" is simple (that was my intention when I implemented it): when we receive a request, we search for expired resources and delete them, that easy. This patch is adding this timeout not to delete any existing reservation when creating a new resource.

neutron/db/quota/driver_nolock.py.message: So this one is called out of resource creation scope, and DB error/retry here won't lead to the bug, right?

No, at this point we can fail. If the reservation removal fails, we retry the whole operation. This is called at the beginning of the API call.

What we don't want to retry is the "remove_reservation" call (called in L78 "cancel_reservation"). This is called at the end of the API call, when the resource has been created (or not) and we don't want, at this point, to retry anything.

doc/source/admin/ovn/availability_zones..message: Is this needed to place a node in an AZ? Thinking about compute nodes not acting as gateways, it may be simpler for deployments to just put all nodes from a site in AZ (and enable chassis as gateway on networker/computes with external connectivity)

It's not needed but in ML2/OVN it doesn't make much sense to add AZs to nodes that are not gateways. Allow me to explain.

For both cases for AZs we have, which are: 1) Router ports (Router AZ) and 2) External ports (Network AZ) they both require the ports to be scheduled on gateway nodes so only those that *also* contains the "enable-chassis-as-gw" value will be considered as candidates for scheduling these types of ports.

That said, if one wants to set the availability-zones options on a node that is not a gateway node it won't do any harm; We just do not have a use-case for it at this moment in ML2/OVN.

charms_ceph/utils.py.message: osd_path already has the initial os.sep so this ends up being something like //var/lib/ceph/osd/ceph-2. If I'm not mistaken, you simply need os.path.join(osd_path, osd_dir) here.

`os.path.join` appears to recognize such cases:


```
>>> path = os.path.join (os.sep, 'var', 'lib')
>>> path
'/var/lib'
>>> os.path.join (os.sep, path, 'foo')
'/var/lib/foo'
```

and the documentation states:
join(a, *p)
    Join two or more pathname components, **inserting '/' as needed**.
    If any component is an absolute path, all previous path components
    will be discarded.  An empty last part will result in a path that
    ends with a separator.

I think passing in the tenants won't work as the executors will also create a Nodepool instance, but they don't have a layout.

In case the Nodepool API is created as part of the scheduler it will also receive the scheduler instance. You can use that to directly access the list of tenants via self.sched.abide.tenants.

From my perspective - currently working on the config loading in a multi-scheduler setup - I'd avoid having to update the list of tenants here whenever the abide changes.

But that's just my two cents ...

I thought we wanted to get rid of the scheduler reference here eventually. Therefore passed in the tenants separately as I wanted to avoid a new reference to something that's ought to be removed.
Wouldn't it be also okay to have the tenant param be empty in case the executor creates the instance and then just skip the corresponding stats?
Otherwise, I can of course remove the tenant param and use scheduler.abide.tenants instead (I think we had it this way before, and then changed it because of the above reason).

Under what circumstances would a request's tenant be unknown?

And perhaps we should just omit them here.  The value can be inferred by subtraction from the total requests, and by doing this, we will collide with anyone who sets a tenant name of "unknown" which is plausible.

Emitting this statistic on every node request change (which can be many per second during bursts) is overkill and will have a severe impact on our scheduler performance. Especially since this loops over all node requests we know. Instead we should do this in Scheduler._runStats which is executed periodically instead.
How about we move zuul.nodepool.current_requests too, that way they are in sync?

This is basically O(n^3). Given that get_chassis_availability_zones(chassis) will always return the same set, we could avoid calling it "len(az_list)" time for the same chassis by avoiding set comprehension:

 chassis = set()
 for ch in chassis_list:
     chassis_azs = get_chassis_availability_zones(ch)
     if chassis_azs.intersection(az_list):
         chassis.add(ch.name)

But not sure if ^^ is just premature optimization but given that chassis might be in order of hundred, it might be worth thinking about.

Condition in line 179 checks if there is anything in fips list.
If there isn't we removing port and then there is this notify call that attempts to get first element from empty list which will always end up with IndexError.
this introduces quite a heavy DB request on each port delete, why is it needed? If it's not fixing some bug then please avoid adding DB requests.
+1 on this, do we need the updated FIP in the event? is it used by any listener? if it wasn't before, why now?

- why is it needed? do we need the updated FIP in the event?
Yeah. When publishing AFTER_UPDATE notification we are expected to provide state of the object before and after the change.

- is it used by any listener?
Yup, only _create_dvr_floating_gw_port in l3_dvr_db in Neutron, but it's also quite important in our 3rd party plugin.

- if it wasn't before, why now?
Because previously noone cared too much about content of those notifications it seems.
Every FIP notification had a different field names for same data, and some fields were missing in some of notifications. Working with these was a huge pain.
In case of delete_floatingip previously we were faking creation of FIP state dict in line 1644, but it was missing a couple of fields that _make_floatingip_dict adds.

- this introduces quite a heavy DB request on each port delete
Eh, very true. Another get_objects call was added because update_objects don't change state of objects in floating_ip_objs.

But now when I think about it - we only need FloatingIP objects with updated state for _make_floatingip_dict call, not actual state directly from db.
I'll try to update those without querying DB, it may be enough.

    new_fips = {}

        fip.router_id = None
        new_fips[fip.id] = self._make_floatingip_dict(fip)

neutron_dynamic_routing/services/bgp/bgp.message:
Question for further maintenance:
Is there any reason to use .get() instead of ['network_id']?
'network_id' is always populated by the publisher in the neutron code. IMHO if it is not optional, it is better to use [] operator.

Note that I don't want to block this by this question and vote +2.

The assumption is that we'll always get a network_id here and at L275. In case we don't, the failure would manifest itself in simply failing to revoke or emit routes in response to a change to a router interface. It won't be obvious to users, and even so the problem would iron itself out on the next the next agent re-sync (by default every 30 seconds). gw_network being set to None shouldn't cause a stack trace, and within 30 seconds all the proper routes would be located and sent to the agent. Because the callback is dealing with router interface events rather than a compute port event, the need to quickly revoke/emit routes isn't that great. IMO we can tolerate a delay here should the worst case scenario strike.

All this is to say, even the worst case scenario where network_id isn't set on the payload doesn't constitute a bug with major (or even easily visible) impact.

I'm not sure if it was by mistake or by purpose TBH but patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/801453 which switched to payloads in AFTER_* events for floating ips changed event emited in create_floatingip() method. Earlier it was emited as AFTER_UPDATE - see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/801453/4/neutron/db/l3_db.py
Because of that it was handled by that floatingip_update_callback always.
But now it is emited with AFTER_CREATE event (which IMO makes sense TBH) thus You probably need to add something like:

    registry.subscribe(self.floatingip_update_callback,
                       resources.FLOATING_IP,
                       events.AFTER_CREATE)

here
This should be changed too. That receives a neutron.db.models.l3.Router in a payload.
+1 - that change is necessary as Rodolfo mentioned.

2. For Show. PUT, Rebuild and List detail API response, show_extended_attr was evaluated by policy[1] and making policy checks microversion based is not good (as you know policy changes are not microversion-ed).

This end up policy checks controlled by microversion which is what we do not do right. As proposed in spec, we want hostname to be shown to all users(not controlled by policy) this means we want to remove the policy checks for all the old or new microversion. Means any non-admin will be able to see this for >2.3(for GET, >2.75 for Put/Rebuild) also. This is how we change the policy (if we remove policy or add/modify policy it is done for old microversion too). 

I think you are confusing it because policy change is proposed along with API change spec. But that can be done separately even later then spec change.

As this is policy change (leaving API change apart), I am saying we should do it 'without microversion control' and 'with deprecation phase'

we discussed it on IRC too and i am convinced to do this way so that end user can use the API change done in 2.90 completely.  along with this we can deprecate the policy in this and remove from next cycle so that we do not need to control the ``OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname`` field with policy for all the microversion it was added in.

I'm not 100% sure I got the whole issue. We remove a policy check from hostname in 2.90 as we want to show that to everybody going forward but keep it in <2.90 as we don't want to break old behavior. 

I guess we can look at it from two equally valid perspective:
a) it is microversion change: no deprecation period is needed as old microversions are still supported
b) it is a policy default change: no microversion bump is needed, but it needs a deprecation period

For me a) seems to be the simpler process to follow right now.

please ignore my 1st point. list (non-detail) response does not call Show() method so no issue for list response.

on 2nd point. yes we need to remove the 2.89 condition as we are just removing the policy checks for hostname attribute. But I prefer to remove the policy check with deprecation phase.

In this microversion:
---------
1.  we can just leave this file unchanged (mean keep returning hostname only for admin by default even non-admin able to pass it in request for >=2.89 microversion)
2. Add deprecation in policy in this cycle.

This way we will saying to user- "you can pass the hostname to set on instance but you will not see it in response if current policy does not allow you but we are deprecating the policy and in next nova version you can see it always".

---------

In next cycle:
-----------
1. Remove it from policy and change this file to return hostname for non-admin case also.
2. But we need to handle the previous microversion check where this attribute was added. Because this Show() view method is used for Show/List-detail and PUT/Rebuild API response microversion are different:

- 2.3 added in for SHOW and List Detail API response
- 2.75 added in PUT and Rebuild API response (currently it is handled by show_extended_attr arg only[1][2])

we can add a new kwargs to handle the above different micorversion in different API:
- Removing hostname from L326
- add a new kwargs show_hostname=True by default(for SHOW and List Details APIs):
- PUT and Rebuild will pass it as per 2.75 microversion check[1][2]
 
And we can have condition in show() method like below:

if show_hostname and api_version_request.is_supported(request, min_version='2.3'):
    server["server"]["OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname"] = \
                        instance.hostname
(
- for Show/List-detail: show_hostname is True by default so we add it for >=2.3 only
- for PUT/Rebuild: show_hostname will be passed as True only for >=2.75 so 2nd condition of >=2.3 is always valid.
)

[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/691f24b8a58c3234de09dfe614655b9c98b51b39/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L1235-L1247

-------------

I've thought about this a lot and I still don't like it 😄 I think we're conflating two things here.

- The *policy* is used to configure whether extended server attributes are returned in responses for non-admins or not.
- The *microversion* is changing the definition of the 'hostname' attribute from an extended server attribute to a standard (i.e. not extended) server attribute (unfortunately it will still retain the 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR' prefix, but that's for other reasons).

These are two separate things. This attribute is still an "extended" attribute in previous microversions, meaning it makes sense for this to continue to be controlled via policy. Once we hit 2.90 (previously 2.89, but lyarwood got the 2.89 microversion) then it's no longer controlled via policy. If we don't do this, then users will suddenly start seeing 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname' in responses for microversions 2.3 - 2.89 (or 2.75 - 2.89 for update and rebuild) once we deprecate the policy. That is not what we want. As a result, I think we should keep this as I've done it.

wdyt?

I'm not entirely sure what you're asking for here. I think you're saying that I shouldn't have the "is microversion 2.89" check here and instead always add the 'hostname' attribute for everything except the list servers (non-detail) response. Is that correct?
can you add a TODO here about to remove the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname policy checks and then we can remove the 2.90 version condition.

Done in a follow-up, because I'm still not entirely sure this is the correct approach to follow. I understand that microversions and policy and two separate things that shouldn't be conflated. However, I think what I said previously makes sense and the microversion is changing the *type* of attribute that 'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hostname' is. This "type" is unchanged for previous microversions, meaning the policy should stay, IMO.

We can debate that a little more on the follow-up patch.

doc/source/devref/lbaas_reconciliation_d.message: well, rather than maintain the same "status" as in the CRD, the idea is that we ensure whatever is on the "spec" section of the CRD is on OpenStack side, and then we update the "status" of the CRD with the new/recovered/recreated OpenStack resources

There is no such an API in OpenStack. So you cannot "watch" for changes in the same way as we do for K8s resources. It will require some pooling from time to time to ensure what we thought it was on OpenStack side is still there and react it not.

I would say that if some resources on OpenStack are missing, what we need to do is to remove them from the associated KuryrLoadBalancer CRD status, so that the KuryrLoadBalancerHandler react to it (re-executes the on_present function) and by executing the sync_lbaas_member function reconciles it as it does today (i.e., recovering the existing resources, recreating the missing ones). There is no need to duplicate that on another handler/driver. Just to trigger the execution of the already in place code
there is no such a thing (unless we connect to the rabbitmq or ovn-sb db from Kuryr, and that is only for admin, so, no option for kuryr). We need to do pooling instead
see previous comment. No need for this driver to recreate the Octavia resources, just triggering the existing driver to force the recreation
maybe add something like: (e.g., due to the Octavia loadbalancer being stuck on PENDING_UPDATE)

can the reconciliation mechanism be leveraged here?
https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/watcher.py#L137-L157

the handler already has the CRD object, the following might fit better: "the
KuryrLoadBalancerHandler sets the CRD status field to `empty`"

setting the KLB CRD status to empty won't trigger the ServiceHandler or EndpointHandler. Those Handlers are watching for services and endpoints objects respectively. Modifying/Removing the spec/status of the KLB CRD will trigger the KuryrLoadBalancer Handler

Seems only used for networking binding DHCP agent in network scheduling process. Renaming the function is good for code reading to specify what is this function is doing.

I'm thinking about it from caller code perspective: if I see 'scheduler.bind()' somewhere I expect that it will rather do binding or fail; when I read further code I assume binding was done. Skipped DB error and unsuccessful binding is kind of unexpected in caller code, and seems not quite correct.
try/except in caller code is explicit and clear. "scheduler.try_bind()" is not that explicit but still suggests that binding might not be done after it.
but it's part of Base class, I'm not sure if we should change name of it just like that :)

I'm not going to change a base class method name, regardless of the use, in this patch. If needed, that could be done opening another bug.

The decorator itself is changing the function. You need to read both, the decorator and the method name. The method is not trying to bind, it is actually binding and failing if not possible. The decorator is the one skipping any defined error.

This is not jinja but hiera/puppet syntax, this is why I couldn't just assign the memcached_node_ips list, which is a hiera variable.

The issue itself is with the tempest run being slower when FQDNs are used for memcached servers. It manifested itself with IPv6 without TLS (FS035), when external DNS is used. I think this wouldn't be an issue with TLS, since this setup would use the DNS included in FreeIPA.


tls+ips wouldn't currently work, because the certificates for Memcached are only created for FQDNs

> Ok. The syntax threw me because I'm only familar with "%{hiera(...)}".   Can we just do:
> 
>   memcache_node_names: "%{hiera('memcache_node_ips')}" 
> 
> That would prevent issues if we don't have 3 nodes

I think it would put out a string value like "['1st ip', '2nd ip', '3rd ip']" as the value, so that won't work.

Hey Alex, I tested it here: https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/testproject/+/35061 so it works. Do you have an alternative in mind?

The other way I was thinking of accomplishing this is to have a hiera value like use_memcached_node_ips, which would then have to be checked in all service Memcached configurations (20 files in puppet-tripleo), and then just switch that one value in this environment file.

It works in this specific configration. I'm concerned about the usage of jinja here and i'm not even sure how it's working correctly.  This seems to be a blocker with ipv6+tls configurations and I'm not certain that switching to dns name is correct. IIUC the switch to names was for tls for memcache correct?  If a customer has tls everywhere + ipv6, they will likely hit this and switching to IPs is probably not going to fly. Alternatively if tls+ips works, why did we switch to names at all?

Ok. The syntax threw me because I'm only familar with "%{hiera(...)}".   Can we just do:

  memcache_node_names: "%{hiera('memcache_node_ips')}" 

That would prevent issues if we don't have 3 nodes

octavia/tests/functional/amphorae/backen.message: nit: IPv6 addresses are typically /64, but this is just verifying the file contents.  If it's SLAAC it actually has to be /64.

I didn't change that part, it was already /32 in the network-scripts/interfaces tests (see line 1210 for the parameters of the post request).
So I don't want to change it (it's a functional test and I prefer testing corner cases - /64 is too symmetrical, I don't like to test it in case of bit field manipulations)
I understand it was already /32 just wanted to point out you will probably only ever see a local address configured with a /64 as it's the natural prefix boundary.

Some of my IPv6 brain has been swapped-out, but another perfectly valid gateway address would be a link-local, in fact it's typical on a network:

$ ip -6 r list default
default via fe80::1e3b:f3ff:fed6:8730 dev eno1 proto ra metric 100 pref medium
but I believe that these link-local addresses/routes are automatically added by linux, they should not be included in configuration files

They should both be inter-changeable, as the next-hop must be directly reachable, which implies it's on-link :)  And in some cases operators will actually configure things like fe80::5 on routers to use a the next-hop.

It actually dates back to RFC 4861 (ND), found this good article:

https://oswalt.dev/2013/03/ipv6-next-hop-best-practices/

You don't have to change it, maybe I'm just remembering the day when it had to be a link-local.
